articles.title: DECEMBER 1988
articles.summary: The December 1988 newsletter outlines an astronomy association's activities, featuring a lecture by Richard Hoagland on the "Face on Mars" and several star parties with detailed celestial timings. The schedule also includes board meetings, holiday breaks, and initial January 1989 events such as another star party, a general meeting, and the resumption of an introductory astronomy class.

articles.title: BY: JOHN GLEASON and JIM VAN NULAND
articles.summary: The article announces an upcoming talk by Dick Hoagland regarding the 'Face on Mars' images captured by the Viking orbiter in 1976. It also informs members of a change in the General Meeting date from the first to the second Saturday of the month to accommodate New Moon star parties. Additionally, there's a reminder about an ongoing competition for a new membership card design, offering a free year's membership to the winner.

articles.title: BY: DENISE HUTSON
articles.summary: Don Grabski, a former Delray employee and SJAA member, is moving to Auburn, California, for a new home offering significantly darker night skies, a move eagerly anticipated as his telescope is already there. The article also announces that Denise Hutson is stepping into Don's former role as a reporter for the newsletter, thanking him for his past contributions.

articles.title: ASTRO ADS
articles.summary: This document compiles classified advertisements from late 1988, featuring a diverse range of astronomical equipment for sale, including various telescopes, mounts, eyepieces, and astrophotography accessories. It also includes 'wanted' listings for specific issues of Telescope Making magazine, with contact details and pricing.

articles.title: BY: JIM VAN NULAND
articles.summary: An amateur astronomer reports observing two previously unseen white ovals within Jupiter's South Equatorial Belt, just east of the Great Red Spot, during a period of excellent seeing on October 21st. The article also discusses various Jovian satellite events like transits and occultations, noting historical instances of no satellites being visible. It concludes with a table listing predicted dates and times when Jupiter's Great Red Spot will appear central on the planet's disk.

articles.title: SHUTTLE ORBITER ATLANTIS IS SCHEDULED FOR NOVEMBER LAUNCH
articles.summary: The Space Shuttle Atlantis is scheduled for a November launch, potentially as early as the 28th or 29th, from its launchpad where it arrived on November 2nd. Its secret payload, a Pentagon satellite, was installed on November 10th. A five-man crew will spend 3-4 days in space before landing at Edwards Air Force Base.

articles.title: SOVIET SHUTTLE SUCCESSFULLY LAUNCHED
articles.summary: This document consists of several classified advertisements for used astronomical equipment and related literature. Items for sale include various telescopes (e.g., Bausch & Lomb 60mm, Celestron Super C8+), eyepieces, astrophotography accessories like off-axis guiders and camera mounts, and astronomy handbooks. Each listing provides details on the item's condition, price, and contact information.

articles.title: BURAN SPACECRAFT LAUNCHED
articles.summary: The Soviet Buran spacecraft successfully launched and orbited on November 15th, completing three unmanned orbits before landing by remote control. An earlier launch attempt on October 29th was halted just seconds before liftoff due to sensor retraction issues. A second orbiter, Ptichka, is complete, with up to three more orbiters under construction.

articles.title: MIR COSMONAUTS REPAIR X-RAY TELESCOPE
articles.summary: Mir cosmonauts successfully repaired an X-ray telescope during a four-hour Extravehicular Activity (EVA) on October 20. This successful spacewalk rectified an issue that a previous repair attempt on June 30 had failed to address due to a broken tool.

articles.title: PHOBOS-1 REVIVAL ATTEMPTS ABANDONED
articles.summary: The Soviet Union has officially abandoned attempts to revive its Phobos-1 spacecraft, which is currently en route to Mars and its moon Phobos. It is theorized that the spacecraft has stabilized in a gravity gradient attitude, causing its solar panels to point away from the Sun, preventing power generation.

articles.title: GOES-WEST WEATHER SATELLITE FAILS
articles.summary: The GOES-WEST weather satellite failed in early November, exceeding its design life after a critical light bulb burned out in its imager system. This leaves GOES-East as the sole operational weather satellite for at least 18 months, requiring seasonal repositioning. Additionally, the article outlines the 1989 Space Shuttle launch schedule, detailing missions such as deploying satellites and interplanetary probes.

articles.title: DOUBLE, TRIPLE AND MULTIPLE STARS BY: PATRICK DONNELLY
articles.summary: This article, 'DOUBLE, TRIPLE AND MULTIPLE STARS' by Patrick Donnelly, provides a curated list of interesting double, triple, and multiple stars observable in early December, suitable for beginners. It includes observing tips such as optimal viewing times and telescope power, along with a table detailing star names, magnitudes, separations, and color notes. The guide encourages new astronomers to explore these celestial objects using an Edmund Mag 5 Star atlas.

articles.title: BY: DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: Don Machholz reports on the fading Comet Temple 2 and the discovery of two new sungrazing comets, SMM 4 and SMM 5, by the Solar Maximum Mission Satellite. He also announces his new role as Comet Recorder for the Association of Lunar and Planetary Observers (ALPO), inviting observations. The article details the characteristics of these short-lived sungrazers and discusses the challenges and potential methods for daytime comet observation.

articles.title: PERIODIC COMET TEMPLE 2 (1987g)
articles.summary: This document provides an ephemeris for Periodic Comet Temple 2 (1987g) detailing its Right Ascension, Declination, Elongation, and Magnitude from November 1987 through early January. It notes that the comet was setting around 10 PM local time from most of the U.S., allowing observers time to view its impressive six-month show.

articles.title: SEEKING COMETS
articles.summary: This article analyzes seasonal patterns in comet discoveries across four datasets: amateur visual (1975-1987), historical visual (1700-1985), historical photographic (1700-1985), and satellite-found Sungrazers. It identifies a significant Northern Hemisphere observational bias, with Autumn months generally showing a higher percentage of discoveries for visual and photographic methods due to favorable clear, long nights and optimal ecliptic orientation. The article discusses factors influencing these trends, including weather and sky coverage.

articles.title: YES STARS REALLY DO MOVE!
articles.summary: Todd Hansen undertook a multi-year visual observing project to personally verify the proper motion of stars, focusing primarily on Barnard's Star. Using hand-drawn charts between 1977 and 1983, he successfully detected its movement over a two to three-year period, demonstrating that visual methods can confirm the phenomenon qualitatively, though precise yearly measurements require photographic techniques.

articles.title: GENERAL MEETINGS
articles.summary: The SJAA holds monthly General Meetings at the Red Cross building in Los Gatos, California, featuring guest speakers on a wide range of astronomical topics and informal "Indoor Star Parties." These gatherings foster a friendly atmosphere for members interested in astrophotography, deep sky observation, telescope making, and more. Meetings occur on the 1st Saturday of each month, with doors opening at 7:45 PM and the meeting beginning at 8 PM.

articles.title: INDOOR STAR PARTIES
articles.summary: The article describes "INDOOR STAR PARTIES" as informal Saturday evening gatherings for amateur astronomers to socialize, discuss astronomy, and share equipment. These events often feature telescope viewing, astrophotography presentations, and can also include organizational board meetings or introductory astronomy workshops.

articles.title: FIELD EXPEDITIONS
articles.summary: The SJAA organizes "Star Parties" for astronomical observation on Saturdays near the New Moon. These events vary in location, from sites close to San Jose to distant places like Yosemite National Park. Participants are advised to check the EPHEMERIS for specific star party locations.

articles.title: FREMONT PEAK STATE PARK
articles.summary: Fremont Peak State Park is a highly popular observing location for Bay Area amateur astronomers, situated 70 miles south of San Jose. It serves as a regular gathering spot for informal camaraderie and excellent observing during New Moon weekends, often attracting 50-100 telescopes, especially in summer. The San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) frequently sets up in Coulter Camp.

articles.title: SAN JOSE ASTRONOMICAL ASSOCIATION MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION
articles.summary: This document is a membership application form for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA). It details different membership tiers, including 'Membership Only', 'Membership/S&T' (likely referring to Sky & Telescope magazine), and 'Junior (Under 18)', along with their respective fees. The form provides instructions for submission, including a mailing address for the treasurer and contact information.
